required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Success of Pediatric Anesthesiologists in Learning to Use Videolaryngoscopes
clinical_study.official_title: Anesthesiologists Learning to Use Videolaryngoscopes in Children

brief_summary.textblock: There are two new instruments on the market that anesthesiologists use when putting a breathing tube into the lungs of patients. The purpose of this study is to see how easily anesthesiologists can learn to use them in children.

detailed_description.textblock: Each anesthesiologist performed 20 timed baseline intubations. They were then randomized to perform 20 timed intubations with one of the two new videolaryngoscopes followed by 20 with the other new videolaryngoscope. The goal was to see how quickly they could become proficient.

primary_outcome.measure: Success in Learning to Use a Videolaryngoscope(VLS)
primary_outcome.description: Anesthesiologists were to perform 20 intubations with each videolaryngoscopes. #1-10 were for practice. "Rapid Success" was no failed intubation attempts on #11-20 and a median time-to-intubation no more than 50% longer than their baseline median time-to-intubation on #11-15 . "Delayed Success" was achieving these same parameters on #16-20 if they were not achieved on #11-15. Operators who did not achieve either goal were labeled as having "No Success".

secondary_outcome.description: This Outcome was designed to determine if the view of the airway as determined by the Cormack & Lehane grading system is improved by use of the GlideScope (GS) video laryngoscope and/or the Karl Storz Direct Coupled Interface (DCI) (KS) video laryngoscope as this would be a surrogate marker for utility in a difficult airway. Score is reported as a whole number from I to IV with I being an easy intubation and IV being one where the larynx cannot be visualized at all.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Intubation, Analyzed by Order of Laryngoscopes Used
secondary_outcome.description: To determine if the learning curve was altered by the order in which the two new laryngoscopes were learned by the anesthesiologist,mean and median times on intubations #16-20 were compared for the two videolaryngoscopes.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Intubation, Stratified by Weight of Patients
secondary_outcome.description: To compare the time-to-intubation for these laryngoscopes in children of different weights.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Years Since Completion of Anesthesiology Residency
secondary_outcome.description: To investigate whether there was a correlation between the years since completion of anesthesiology residency to the mid-point of study (2008)and median time-to-intubation for all first attempt intubations for the study. Years since completion of anesthesiology residency reported in the data table, correlation reported in the statistical analysis below

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Intubation Attempts to Reach "Best Obtainable Time to Intubation"
secondary_outcome.description: For each anesthesiologist, the median time-to-intubation for patients #1-5, #6-10, #11-15, and #16-20 was determined. The anesthesiologist was considered to have reached "Best Obtainable Time (BOT) to Intubation" once the median time on any group of 5 consecutive patients was less than 3 seconds faster than the median time in the previous group of 5 consecutive patients, provided that there were no failed intubations or subsequent failed intubations using the same device.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria for Children Population:
- Children requiring intubation for elective or non-elective surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- Children with raised intracranial pressure
- Children with potential cervical spine injuries
- Children at risk for regurgitation because of a full stomach
- Children who were anticipated to have a difficult airway based on their physical appearance or previous experience were excluded.
Inclusion Criteria for Anesthesiologist Population:
*Anesthesiologists who care for children at Stollery Children's Hospital
Exclusion Criteria for Anesthesiologist Population:
*None

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Children were recruited pre-op if their anesthesiologist was participating in the study. Anesthesiologists did 20 baseline intubations with a standard laryngoscope and then were randomized to use the GlideScope(GS)or Karl Storz Direct Coupled Interface (KS) video laryngoscope (VLS) for 20 intubations), followed by the other VLS.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Patients with anticipated difficult airways were excluded.

group.title: Overall Anesthesiologists
group.description: Baseline intubation times were obtained on a convenience sample of 20 children using the standard laryngoscope blade of their choice. Then anesthesiologists were randomized to complete either 20 intubations with the GlideScope system (GS) video laryngoscope (VLS) or 20 with the Karl Storz Direct Coupled Interface DCI (KS) VLS first. Once they had intubated 20 children with the VLS to which they were randomized, they crossed over to use the alternate VLS for 20 intubations.

group.title: Baseline Intubation Participants
group.description: Children intubated at baseline using the standard laryngoscope blade of the anesthesiologist's choice.

group.title: KS Intubation Participants
group.description: Children intubated with the Karl Storz Direct Coupled Interface DCI (KS) VLS

group.title: GS Intubation Participants
group.description: Children intubated with the GlideScope system (GS) VLS

group.title: Overall Anesthesiologists
group.description: Baseline intubation times were obtained on a convenience sample of 20 children using the standard laryngoscope blade of their choice. Then anesthesiologists were randomized to complete either 20 intubations with the GlideScope system (GS) video laryngoscope (VLS) or 20 with the Karl Storz Direct Coupled Interface DCI (KS) VLS first. Once they had intubated 20 children with the VLS to which they were randomized, they crossed over to use the alternate VLS for 20 intubations.

measure.title: Gender, Customized
measure.description: Gender of the children was not recorded as it was not thought to be of relevance for intubation participants.

outcome.title: Success in Learning to Use a Videolaryngoscope(VLS)
outcome.description: Anesthesiologists were to perform 20 intubations with each videolaryngoscopes. #1-10 were for practice. "Rapid Success" was no failed intubation attempts on #11-20 and a median time-to-intubation no more than 50% longer than their baseline median time-to-intubation on #11-15 . "Delayed Success" was achieving these same parameters on #16-20 if they were not achieved on #11-15. Operators who did not achieve either goal were labeled as having "No Success".
outcome.population: Only anesthesiologists who completed minimum 18 intubations with either laryngoscope were analyzed for the primary outcome.

group.title: GS Intubations
group.description: Anesthesiologists who performed minimum 18 intubations with the GS VLS.

group.title: KS Intubations
group.description: Anesthesiologists who performed minimum 18 intubations with the KS VLS

measure.title: Success in Learning to Use a Videolaryngoscope(VLS)
measure.description: Anesthesiologists were to perform 20 intubations with each videolaryngoscopes. #1-10 were for practice. "Rapid Success" was no failed intubation attempts on #11-20 and a median time-to-intubation no more than 50% longer than their baseline median time-to-intubation on #11-15 . "Delayed Success" was achieving these same parameters on #16-20 if they were not achieved on #11-15. Operators who did not achieve either goal were labeled as having "No Success".
measure.population: Only anesthesiologists who completed minimum 18 intubations with either laryngoscope were analyzed for the primary outcome.

outcome.title: Cormack & Lehane Score
outcome.description: This Outcome was designed to determine if the view of the airway as determined by the Cormack & Lehane grading system is improved by use of the GlideScope (GS) video laryngoscope and/or the Karl Storz Direct Coupled Interface (DCI) (KS) video laryngoscope as this would be a surrogate marker for utility in a difficult airway. Score is reported as a whole number from I to IV with I being an easy intubation and IV being one where the larynx cannot be visualized at all.
outcome.population: Patients were excluded if the Cormack-Lehane score was not recorded.

group.title: GS Intubation Participants
group.description: Children intubated with the GlideScope system (GS) video laryngoscope (VLS)

group.title: KS Intubation Participants
group.description: Children intubated with the Karl Storz Direct Coupled Interface (DCI) (KS) video laryngoscope (VLS)

group.title: Baseline Intubation Participants
group.description: Children intubated at baseline using the standard laryngoscope of the anesthesiologist's choice

measure.title: Cormack & Lehane Score
measure.description: This Outcome was designed to determine if the view of the airway as determined by the Cormack & Lehane grading system is improved by use of the GlideScope (GS) video laryngoscope and/or the Karl Storz Direct Coupled Interface (DCI) (KS) video laryngoscope as this would be a surrogate marker for utility in a difficult airway. Score is reported as a whole number from I to IV with I being an easy intubation and IV being one where the larynx cannot be visualized at all.
measure.population: Patients were excluded if the Cormack-Lehane score was not recorded.

analysis.p_value_desc: The p-value represents the comparison of the two interventions combined and compared against baseline for Grades III and IV summed together.

outcome.title: Time to Intubation, Analyzed by Order of Laryngoscopes Used
outcome.description: To determine if the learning curve was altered by the order in which the two new laryngoscopes were learned by the anesthesiologist,mean and median times on intubations #16-20 were compared for the two videolaryngoscopes.
outcome.population: Only anesthesiologists who completed minimum 18 intubations with each scope were included. We report the mean of their mean times and the mean of their median times on intubations #16-20 when they should have attained a reasonable skill level.

group.title: GS Intubation Times for Those Who Used GS First
KS Intubation Times for Those Who Used KS First
GS Intubation Times for Those Who Used KS First
KS Intubation Times for Those Who Used GS First

measure.description: To determine if the learning curve was altered by the order in which the two new laryngoscopes were learned by the anesthesiologist,mean and median times on intubations #16-20 were compared for the two videolaryngoscopes.
measure.population: Only anesthesiologists who completed minimum 18 intubations with each scope were included. We report the mean of their mean times and the mean of their median times on intubations #16-20 when they should have attained a reasonable skill level.

outcome.description: To compare the time-to-intubation for these laryngoscopes in children of different weights.

outcome.title: Mean Years Since Completion of Anesthesiology Residency
outcome.description: To investigate whether there was a correlation between the years since completion of anesthesiology residency to the mid-point of study (2008)and median time-to-intubation for all first attempt intubations for the study. Years since completion of anesthesiology residency reported in the data table, correlation reported in the statistical analysis below

measure.title: Mean Years Since Completion of Anesthesiology Residency
measure.description: To investigate whether there was a correlation between the years since completion of anesthesiology residency to the mid-point of study (2008)and median time-to-intubation for all first attempt intubations for the study. Years since completion of anesthesiology residency reported in the data table, correlation reported in the statistical analysis below

analysis.p_value_desc: Correlation between years of experience (all anesthesiologists, pooled) and time to intubation (both GS and KS VLSs, pooled)

outcome.title: Number of Intubation Attempts to Reach "Best Obtainable Time to Intubation"
outcome.description: For each anesthesiologist, the median time-to-intubation for patients #1-5, #6-10, #11-15, and #16-20 was determined. The anesthesiologist was considered to have reached "Best Obtainable Time (BOT) to Intubation" once the median time on any group of 5 consecutive patients was less than 3 seconds faster than the median time in the previous group of 5 consecutive patients, provided that there were no failed intubations or subsequent failed intubations using the same device.

group.description: Anesthesiologists who intubated minimum 18 children with the GS VLS.

group.title: KS Intubations
group.description: Anesthesiologists who intubated minimum 18 children with the KS VLS

measure.title: Number of Intubation Attempts to Reach "Best Obtainable Time to Intubation"
measure.description: For each anesthesiologist, the median time-to-intubation for patients #1-5, #6-10, #11-15, and #16-20 was determined. The anesthesiologist was considered to have reached "Best Obtainable Time (BOT) to Intubation" once the median time on any group of 5 consecutive patients was less than 3 seconds faster than the median time in the previous group of 5 consecutive patients, provided that there were no failed intubations or subsequent failed intubations using the same device.

reported_events.desc: The incidence of trauma was recorded during the study. Failed intubation was one of the outcomes on the study so these events were not specifically recorded as adverse outcomes.

group.title: Overall Anesthesiologists
group.description: Baseline intubation times were obtained on a convenience sample of 20 children using the standard laryngoscope blade of their choice. Then anesthesiologists were randomized to complete either 20 intubations with the GlideScope system (GS) video laryngoscope (VLS) or 20 with the Karl Storz Direct Coupled Interface DCI (KS) VLS first. Once they had intubated 20 children with the VLS to which they were randomized, they crossed over to use the alternate VLS for 20 intubations.

group.title: Baseline Intubation Participants
group.description: Children intubated at baseline using the standard laryngoscope blade of the anesthesiologist's choice

group.title: KS Intubation Participants
group.description: Children intubated with the Karl Storz Direct Coupled Interface (DCI) (KS) video laryngoscope (VLS)

group.title: GS Intubaton Participants
group.description: Children intubated with the GlideScope system (GS) video laryngoscope (VLS)

event.description: Minor trauma was sustained on intubation attempts in two children at baseline, four with the GlideScope (GS) (on intubation attempts 5, 6, 8 and 18) and two with the Karl Storz Direct Coupled Interface(DCI)(KS) on intubation attempts 6 and 16).

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Level of success could only be determined for the 8 anesthesiologists who completed minimum 18 intubations with the GS or KS video laryngoscope. Only 6 of 14 completed the whole study so had data could be used in comparing the two scopes.
